newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks end down, take rest from recent rally.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks end down, take rest from recent rally.

text.p: Mexican stocks broke with a record-breaking run on Monday and closed down on what dealers said was light profit-taking.

"The market took profits at moderate volume while awaiting the outcome of (Tuesday's) primary Cetes auction. The consensus forecast is that rates will increase," said Roberto Galvan, an equity analyst with the Bursametrica consultancy.
Final closing prices placed the blue chip IPC share index down 34.55 points, or 0.83 percent, at 4,126.30. Trading volume was lackluster at 61.8 million.
"Nonetheless, from the volume we can see a tendency among investors to retain their positions," Galvan added.
"The market is taking a breather," a desk trader said. "Jitters over forthcoming elections were present, but it was time for every one to sell."
Mexico will hold elections on July 6 for the entire lower house of Congress, one-quarter of the Senate, mayor of Mexico City and several state governors.
Dealers said May inflation data released in late trade had little impact on the market.

Banco de Mexico announced the Consumer Price Index rose by 0.91 percent in May. This compares with an average forecast increase of 0.92 percent in a previous Reuters forecast of ten Mexico City financial firms.
"The (inflation) data had little effect as it was exactly in line with predictions," a desk trader said.

Financial firm Bancomer weighed down most on the market. Dealers said forecast increases in primary rates, which tend to increase banks' past-due loans burdens, encouraged profit-taking on the B series after it had gained 18 percent last week.
Bancomer's B shares slid 13 centavos to 3.37 pesos, while its A class shares ended off seven centavos 1.86 pesos.

Telecomms firm Telmex succumbed to profit-taking and decoupled its progress from the broad trend on Wall Street, dealers said. Telmex L shares ended down 18 centavos to 18.62 pesos, while its ADRs were off 1/8 at 46-7/8.
The Dow Jones meanwhile climbed 42.72 points to a new record close of 7,478.50.
"A few exporters did well today because of the soft peso, like GCC and Alfa," a desk trader said.
Cement maker Grupo Cementos de Chihuahua gained two centavos to 8.34 pesos, while industrial conglomerate Alfa rose 50 centavos to 48.50 pesos.
Benchmark 48-hour pesos had closed earlier 0.25 of a centavo firmer, but weakened considerably last week.
The broad market matched the declines posted by blue chips. Of a total of 108 stocks traded, decliners outpaced gainers by 58 to 23.
Retailer Sears Roebuck de Mexico ended unchanged at 18.10 pesos after a hefty cross trade.
Monday saw the deadline of a public offering undertaken by Grupo Carso to acquire an additional 25 percent of equity in Sears Mexico through Corporacion de Empresas Comerciales.
Carso had previously acquired a 60-percent stake in Sears Mexico at the beginning of April from Sears Roebuck Co., which now holds 15 percent of the Mexican chain.
(( --Mexico City newsroom +525 728-7907))
